data.title: Core Lab
data.content:
Where each core sample of gross cane is weighed, pressed,
pressed, the juice analyzed, and the bagasse dried.

data.title: % Sediment
data.content:
The amount of soil and other insoluble solids in the cane juice.
It also approximates the amount of soil in the gross cane.
Dry Sediment (80%fiber) has a very deleterious effect on Cane Fiber.

data.title: Adjusted Grams Bagasse
data.content:
The weighed amount of bagasse (cane plus leaves, tops, grass, sediment) remaining after
pressing the sample. TRS is based on two opposing components:
 weight and quality of juice vs weight and quality of bagasse.

data.title: Pol Reading
data.content: A measurement of sucrose using a polarimeter.

data.title: Moisture % Bagasse
data.content: Moisture determined by drying the bagasse sample in an oven. Used to calculate Fiber.

data.title: Juice Brix
data.content: The amount of all soluble solids (sugars and non-sugars) dissolved in the cane juice.

data.title: Juice Pol
data.content:
Percentage of sucrose in the juice; used instead of 'sucrose' to denote determination by
polarimeter. A one point decrease in juice pol decreases
 TRS by 15 lbs. Pol is the single most important factor in determining TRS.

data.title: Juice Purity
data.content: How much of the brix is pure sucrose.

data.title: Fibraque
data.content:
Amount of Fiber in the gross cane. Includes all extraneous material.
Net cane fibercan range anywhere from 10-15% depending on variety
and crop cycle. Soil (80% fiber), leaves (50% fiber), tops (20% fiber), plus
 roots and grass all increase fiber. The second most important
 factor effecting TRS.

data.title: Cane: Brix, Pol, Fibrq
data.content: Qualities expressed as percentage of the gross cane delivered.

data.title: Gross cane
data.content: Cane as delivered including trash (leaves, tops, roots, grass, sediment)

data.title: Statistical Note
data.content:
Gross Sugarcane as delivered is not a very homogenous material.
The statistical error of any given sample is 7% on average.
This drops to 3.5% for 4 samples,
 and 0.84% for 70 samples.
A grower with just 3 samples per day on a 100 day crop would have a statistical error of only 0.40%,
 or less than one pound of sugar.
